body: same with resnet

How do you test the performance? Would you paste your code?

I think there's some trick to evaluate the time of forward and backward. Since `forward` and `backward` call only push the ops to engine and return immediately, and in `update_metric` function, it needs to get the output result from engine (mainly call `asnumpy()`), which means `update_metric` will wait `forward` and `backward` finishes.
I just did a pull request.

@piiswrong 
Hi, Eric. 
I think I found the reason. 
It is in the mx.module.base_module.fit line 486-487

[fit](https://github.com/dmlc/mxnet/blob/master/python/mxnet/module/base_module.py#L486-L487)

After I changed
```
self.forward_backward(data_batch)
self.update()
```
to 
```
mod.forward(data_batch=data_batch,is_train=True)
mod.backward()
mod.update()
``` 
outside of mod.fit scope. 
Everything just works fine. I used `make_loss` to generate the loss.
I think it is due to 
`make_loss` operation somehow needs some additional attention (it became a list?). 

The error message is so confusing. Does `backward` operation on loss layer uses reduce op??
@jk314  running out of space on the disk. Thanks!!! :+1:

latest in https://software.intel.com/en-us/performance-libraries 
you could check mkl_version.h #define __INTEL_MKL_BUILD_DATE 20170127

@luoyetx many thanks for your response. Based on the information you offered, I probably used a wrong way to measure time costs for `forward` and `backward`. I just measured the time cost for `forward_backward` here, 
https://github.com/dmlc/mxnet/blob/master/python/mxnet/module/base_module.py#L190
https://github.com/dmlc/mxnet/blob/master/python/mxnet/module/base_module.py#L191
The time costs I got should just be the time cost that pushing the ops to the engine. (Also I measured the time cost of `update_metric` through this line https://github.com/dmlc/mxnet/blob/master/python/mxnet/module/base_module.py#L495, whose time cost is quite high).
Can you show me the tricks to get the real time cost for `forward_backward` and `update_metric`?
Also, do you have effective way(s) to remove the `update_metric` for train-accuracy and only implement it on validation data like from this line( https://github.com/dmlc/mxnet/blob/master/python/mxnet/module/base_module.py#L524)?
Thank you very much.

Temporary solution: change the cmakelists.txt from:

```
if(${CMAKE_SYSTEM_NAME} STREQUAL "Darwin" AND USE_MXNET_LIB_NAMING)
  add_library(mxnet MODULE ${SOURCE})
else()
  if(UNIX)
    add_library(mxnet_static STATIC ${SOURCE})
    # Need an arbitrary source file to trigger CMake to build the library
    add_library(mxnet SHARED)
    # This has prolems, as it adds libmxnet_static to INTERFACE_LINK_LIBRARIES
    target_link_libraries(mxnet "-Wl,--whole-archive $<TARGET_FILE:mxnet_static> -Wl,--no-whole-archive")
    target_link_libraries(mxnet mxnet_static) # Let cmake understand the dependency
    add_custom_target(
        StaticallyLinkStaticMXNetLibrary ALL
        BYPRODUCTS ${CMAKE_ARCHIVE_OUTPUT_DIRECTORY}/libmxnet.a
        WORKING_DIRECTORY ${CMAKE_ARCHIVE_OUTPUT_DIRECTORY}
        COMMAND ln -sf libmxnet_static.a libmxnet.a
        DEPENDS mxnet_static
    )
  else()
    add_library(mxnet SHARED ${SOURCE})
  endif()
endif()
```

to 

```
add_library(mxnet SHARED ${SOURCE})
```

It works in mac and ubuntu.

@CarlosUziel I am adding an R example for captcha recognition. https://github.com/dmlc/mxnet/pull/6443

Each image like below has 4 labels, and we trained a CNN over them.

![test](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/1547093/26460795/b6ed6b1e-412f-11e7-8cc5-61d3f56bb21e.png)

I hope this example helps.

@yib2 

@CarlosUziel I am adding an R example for captcha recognition. https://github.com/dmlc/mxnet/pull/6443

Each image like below has 4 labels, and we trained a CNN over them.

![test](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/1547093/26460795/b6ed6b1e-412f-11e7-8cc5-61d3f56bb21e.png)

The `lst` file is like below:

```
0	8	1	4	7	test/ocr_0.png
1	6	7	9	2	test/ocr_1.png
2	9	6	1	9	test/ocr_2.png
3	4	7	7	8	test/ocr_3.png
```

I hope this example helps.

@nicklhy As I mentioned before, we did not do any inference tests ourselves, so I don't have a good intuition whether those results look fine, but FWIW, I tested your script on P100 and got this for ResNet50:

| Batch size  | speed |
| --------------- | -------- |
| 1  | 147  |
| 2  | 248  |
| 4 | 388 |
| 8 | 506 |
| 16 | 589 |
| 32 | 661 |
| 64 | 696 |
| 128 | 709 |

So I don't really see the problem there... Is the Titan X Pascal result the old Titan X or the new one (perfect)? Also, what is the version of MXNet you are testing it on?

@piiswrong This tests the _installation instructions_ to make sure that the guide works. The testing in mxnet-distro needs to happen too, but that is a separate in-progress item.

Hi @huangguanMayday 
This has been fixed by this [this](https://github.com/dmlc/mxnet/pull/6389) and [this](https://github.com/dmlc/mxnet/pull/6436). Let us know if this still doesn't work.
In some case, we would like a separate `relu` operator, although we do not have the plan to deprecate `Activation` operator.

pip install depends on the pip package which is not in this repo. Putting it here can cause test fails without changes in mxnet repo. These tests should be moved into mxnet-distro

source install tests can be here.
also need to update version for backend and other language bindings

I advocate to push this in because
- this should only run if there is a change to install.md installation guide and we need to make sure those pass
- we're in progress of moving mxnet-distro into mxnet anyway @szha

Does this work?

https://github.com/dmlc/mxnet/blob/84f1f2e4346ea90b0d9f77405631b688b76ad98f/example/numpy-ops/weighted_logistic_regression.py

I've added the tests in mxnet-distro for the immediate release.

Eric has a point that having external dependencies for tests is bad and unless we mock the dependencies there isn't a way around it. Also, adding a test for `pip install mxnet` doesn't help much anyways. Ly, see if you could find a way to mock the invocation of commands, or come up with a better way, or exclude the pip command from doc tests.
@wangg12 did you figure out? Thanks a lot in advance.
or maybe calling push and pull is run by a single thread

comm_buf is NDArray, which means all the operations on top of them are scheduled, as opposed to executed immediately, if pull or pull called twice with different keys, they will be serialized properly

@patricianing By 'synsets', do you mean the mapping from geo-coordinate (latitude, longitude) to geographical cell?  
For instance, the mapping such as (lat:37.12, lon:122.23) --> (cell#12)?
